title: That Tallow Balm That Smells Like a Fancy Hotel Soap
body:
So I’m sitting here, my hands are basically sandpaper. It’s winter, the heater’s been blasting, and my skin’s just given up. Feels like paper. I was scrolling, you know how you do, and I saw this thing about a whipped tallow balm. Beef fat. For your face. And hands. I was like, okay that’s weird. But the jar looked nice. And it said it was made in France. And the scent was ‘Pear’. Not ‘French Pear’ or ‘Pear Blossom’. Just… Pear. I was curious. So I got it. This Whipped Tallow Balm in Pear. I didn’t expect much but honestly, the whole thing is kind of a vibe. It’s the scent, mostly. Makes putting beef fat on your skin feel less… medieval.

Anyway. It showed up in this little box. The neighbor’s dog was barking. I opened it right there in my kitchen, light was kinda yellow, you know that late afternoon light. The jar’s heavy. Cold. I unscrewed the lid.

## What This Pear Tallow Balm Actually Smells Like

Okay so. It doesn’t smell like beef. At all. That was my first worry. It doesn’t smell like a candle either, or like super fake candy pear. It’s hard to describe scents. I’m bad at it. It’s like… you know when you’re a kid and you get those fruit-shaped erasers? It’s not that plastic smell. It’s more like if you walked past a bakery that was making a pear tart, but you’re across the street. You get a little sweetness in the air. A fresh one. Not cooked. Just… there. It’s light. It doesn’t punch you in the face. It’s just nice. Gentle. Makes the whole experience of using this natural pear skincare thing feel sophisticated, I guess? But not in a snobby way. In a “oh, this is pleasant” way. My sister smelled it over the phone. I held the jar up to my phone, which is ridiculous, and she was like “I smell nothing.” So it’s subtle. But it’s there. It’s the reason I keep reaching for it. A scented tallow balm that doesn’t smell like a farm is a win.

## How I Started Smearing Beef Fat on My Face

Look. I was skeptical. My routine was a bunch of expensive bottles that did nothing. My skin was tight and flaky and angry. Red patches near my nose. Eczema? Maybe. Psoriasis? Who knows. The dermatologist just gave me a cream that made it worse. So I was done. I read that beef tallow, like the grass-fed kind, is weirdly close to the oil our own skin makes. Our sebum. So it sinks in deep. Doesn’t just sit on top. This one’s whipped, so it’s not like lard in a can. It’s fluffy. Airy. Texture was weird at first. Not bad weird. It’s solid in the jar but when you scoop some, it melts. Like, immediately. You put a dab on your finger and by the time you’re moving it to your cheek, it’s already turning to oil. It’s not greasy. It’s… I don’t know. It just disappears. My face drinks it. I use it at night, after I wash my face. Sometimes in the morning if I’m feeling dry. I just scoop a little, warm it between my fingers, and pat it on. The pear scent is the best part. It’s this little moment of something fresh and sweet before bed. Makes it feel like a treat, not a chore. I got mine from this little Etsy shop that makes them in small batches. Feels more personal than some factory, you know?

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

So the results. I didn’t want to jinx it. But after like, a week? My face stopped feeling like a desert. The tightness was gone. After two weeks, the red patches by my nose… calmed down. They’re not gone gone, but they’re not angry anymore. They’re just… there. But the real shocker was my hands. I work with my hands a lot. Wash them constantly. In winter they crack. Like, bleed sometimes. It’s bad. I started using this tallow balm on them at night. Just slathering it on before bed. Put on some cheap cotton gloves. Woke up and my hands were… normal. Soft. Not “baby soft” that’s a weird phrase. Just… mine. But hydrated. The cracks healed. My knuckles aren’t white and scaly. I keep the jar by my bed now. The pear scent is so light it doesn’t bother me. It’s just a nice little thing. I’m on my second jar now. I told my mom about it. She has psoriasis on her elbows. She was horrified at first. “Beef fat?!” But I gave her a little sample and she texted me last week asking for the link. That’s the thing. It just works. I don’t know the science. I just know my skin’s happy. And smelling a faint, fresh pear while I’m doing it is a bonus I didn’t know I needed.

## Would I Buy This Pear Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. Like I said, second jar. It’s become this non-negotiable thing in my winter routine. It’s not magic. It’s not going to make you look 20 again. But if your skin is dry, or irritated, or just feeling off… this stuff helps. It really does. It’s simple. One ingredient, basically, plus the natural scent. No crazy chemical list. No perfume that gives me a headache. Just this whipped beef tallow balm that smells like a quiet, fresh pear. It feels like a secret. A weird, old-school secret that actually works. My elbows haven’t been this smooth since… I don’t know when. High school? Anyway. If your skin is being difficult, this pear tallow balm might be worth a shot. It’s one of those things you try because you’re desperate and then you get kinda mad that something so simple fixed what a hundred-dollar cream couldn’t.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. From what I read, it’s super similar to the oils our own skin produces. So it absorbs deep instead of sitting on top and clogging things. My face seems to recognize it. It just… eats it up.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And I can get clogged pores easy. Because it’s so similar to our skin’s stuff, it sinks right in. Doesn’t feel like a layer of gunk. It feels like nothing, which is the point.

**What does the Pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s not a strong candy smell. It’s light. Fresh. Like the idea of a pear, not a Jolly Rancher. A tiny bit sweet, but clean. It’s gentle. Makes using it actually enjoyable.

So yeah. It just works. I don’t know what else to say. My skin’s happy, I’m happy, that’s all I wanted. Might order another one soon just to have as backup.
random_tangent: I told my sister about this
